questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with hypocalcemia, thymic hypoplasia, cardiac abnormalities, and deletion of chromosome 22q11.2?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) DiGeorge syndrome

Explanation:

  • DiGeorge syndrome (22q11.2 deletion syndrome) is caused by a deletion on the long arm of chromosome 22. It is characterised by hypocalcemia, thymic hypoplasia, and cardiac abnormalities and occurs in 1 in 4000 births. The condition is often overlooked due to its variable clinical features.

 

These features include:

  • Congenital heart defects
  • Abnormalities of the palate
  • Facial dysmorphism
  • Developmental delay
  • T-cell immunodeficiency
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Key features:
    • Thymic hypoplasia leading to T-cell immunodeficiency
    • Parathyroid hypoplasia causing hypocalcemia
    • Cardiac malformations affecting the outflow tract
    • Facial anomalies (e.g., mild facial dysmorphology)

Diagnosis: The condition is suspected clinically but confirmed by FISH (Fluorescence in situ hybridisation) testing. Around 90% of DiGeorge syndrome and 80% of velocardiofacial syndrome cases show the 22q11.2 deletion. This test can also identify deletions in individuals with conotruncal cardiac defects but no other features of the syndrome.

 

Williams Syndrome (Option A) is a genetic disorder caused by a deletion on chromosome 7, not 22q11.2. It is characterised by cardiovascular problems, developmental delays, and distinctive facial features, but it does not involve thymic hypoplasia, cardiac abnormalities like those seen in DiGeorge syndrome, or hypocalcemia.

Pitt Syndrome (Option B) is a rare genetic condition linked to mutations in the FLNA gene, leading to developmental and cardiac abnormalities. It doesn’t involve the same chromosome 22q11.2 deletion or the associated features of thymic hypoplasia, immunodeficiency, or hypocalcemia seen in DiGeorge syndrome.

Cri-du-chat Syndrome (Option D) is caused by a deletion on the short arm of chromosome 5. The main features include a distinctive high-pitched cry, intellectual disability, and certain facial features, but it does not include the hallmark features of DiGeorge syndrome, such as thymic hypoplasia, cardiac defects, and hypocalcemia.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female patient presented with a malar rash, recurrent oral ulcers, and multiple joint pains. She has a relevant past history and does not take any medication. Upon further investigations, thrombocytopenia was seen, and the anti-Smith (anti-Sm) antibody was positive. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)

Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis is Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE), an autoimmune disorder that commonly affects young women and presents with features such as:

  • Malar rash (butterfly-shaped rash over the cheeks and nose),
  • Recurrent oral ulcers,
  • Joint pain (often non-erosive arthritis),
  • Thrombocytopenia,
  • Positive anti-Smith (anti-Sm) antibodies, which are highly specific for SLE.
    • While scleroderma, Sjögren syndrome, and rheumatoid arthritis share overlapping symptoms, the positive anti-Sm antibody is most specific to SLE, confirming the diagnosis.

SLE is a chronic autoimmune disease with the production of many antibodies like antinuclear antibodies (ANAs), anti-double-stranded DNA (dsDNA), and anti-Smith (Sm).

  • These autoantibodies form immune complexes that deposit in tissues, causing inflammation and damage.
  • It is more common in women.

Clinical Manifestations of SLE:

  • Skin: Malar rash (butterfly rash), photosensitivity, discoid lesions, and mucosal ulcers.
  • Joints: Non-erosive arthritis commonly affects the hands, wrists, and knees.
  • Renal: Lupus nephritis ranging from asymptomatic proteinuria to severe kidney failure. The major cause of morbidity and mortality in SLE.
  • Cardiovascular: Pericarditis, myocarditis, increased risk of atherosclerosis and coronary artery disease.
  • Pulmonary: Pleurisy and pleural effusion, pulmonary hypertension and interstitial lung.
  • Neurologic: Neuropsychiatric symptoms ranging from headaches and cognitive dysfunction to seizures and psychosis.
  • Hematologic: Anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia. The risk of thrombotic events is increased.

Marker/Antibody

Clinical Significance

Anti-Smith (anti-Sm) antibodies

Highly specific for SLE (<30% of patients)

Anti-dsDNA antibodies

Highly specific for SLE (60-70% of patients); correlates with the disease

Antinuclear antibodies (ANA)

Highly sensitive but not specific for SLE

Anti-Ro (SSA) and Anti-La (SSB) antibodies

Found in SLE and Sjögren syndrome; associated with neonatal lupus

Anti-ribosomal-P antibodies

Specific for neuropsychiatric manifestations in SLE

Anti-histone antibodies

Seen in drug-induced lupus; less specific for SLE

Complements C3 and C4

Low levels indicate complement consumption and disease activity

Explanation:

questions.text: A 78-year-old male presents with fatigue, breathlessness, and palpitations. On examination, he has pedal oedema, with a pulse rate of 55 bpm, BP of 100/70 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 94%. ECG is normal, and echocardiography reveals restrictive cardiomyopathy. A cardiac biopsy stained with Congo red shows apple-green birefringence under polarised light. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cardiac amyloidosis

Explanation:

  • The hallmark feature is apple-green birefringence under polarised light after Congo red staining, characteristic of amyloid deposits.
  • Cardiac amyloidosis causes restrictive cardiomyopathy, presenting with symptoms like fatigue, breathlessness, and oedema.
  • Congo red stain identifies amyloid fibrils in tissue.

Amyloidosis is abnormal extracellular deposits of fibrillar proteins that cause tissue damage and functional compromise.

  • These proteins are misfolded and aggregate, forming amyloid deposits.
  • Amyloid deposits appear as eosinophilic, hyaline, and extracellular substances on hematoxylin and eosin stains.
  • They are confirmed by Congo red staining, which shows red under ordinary light and apple-green birefringence under polarised light.

Morphology: Amyloid deposition is often widespread, but organ involvement can vary:

  • Kidney: Most commonly and severely affected, with amyloid deposits in the glomeruli, arteries, and arterioles.
  • Spleen: Enlarged, showing two patterns of amyloid deposits: "sago spleen" (follicular) and "lardaceous spleen" (sinusoidal).
  • Liver: Amyloid deposits in the space of Disse; liver function is generally preserved despite enlargement.
  • Heart: Commonly involved in senile systemic amyloidosis, with deposits starting subendocardially and in the myocardium.
  • Other organs: May include the tongue (macroglossia), lungs (respiratory tract involvement), and brain (Alzheimer's plaques).

questions.text: Isotype switching is seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Activated B cells

Explanation:

  • Isotype switching, also known as class switching, occurs in activated B cells. This process allows B cells to produce different classes of antibodies (e.g., IgM, IgG, IgA, IgE) in response to specific signals, such as cytokines from helper T cells, during an immune response.

  • Isotype switching, also referred to as class switching or immunoglobulin class switch recombination (CSR), is a process that takes place in activated B cells.
  • During this process, B cells change the class of antibodies they produce, transitioning from IgM to other isotypes such as IgG, IgA, or IgE.
  • Isotype switching enables B cells to generate antibodies with diverse effector functions while preserving the antigen-binding specificity of the original antibody.

IL-4
  • Key cytokine in driving the allergic response
  • Enhances Ig E-mediated reaction
  • Stimulates B cells to undergo class switching to IgE and promotes the expansion of Th2 cells


Defect in class switching - Hyper IgM Syndrome, caused by defects in CD40L (X-linked) or CD40/AID/UNG (autosomal recessive), leads to high IgM with low IgG, IgA, and IgE, causing recurrent infections. Diagnosis involves immunoglobulin levels and genetic testing, with treatment including IVIG and prophylactic antibiotics.

questions.text: A person was brought to the emergency department with facial swelling, itching, and hypotension following a bee sting. The mentioned clinical features are due to an increase in which immunoglobulin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) IgE

Explanation:

  • The clinical features of facial swelling, itching, and hypotension following a bee sting are due to an Allergic Reaction (Type 1 Hypersensitivity Reaction) mediated by the immune system, particularly through IgE (Immunoglobulin E) antibodies.
  • IgE plays a key role in allergic responses by binding to receptors on mast cells and basophils after exposure to an allergen, like bee venom.
  • Upon re-exposure to the allergen, it binds to IgE on mast cells and basophils, triggering the release of histamine, leukotrienes, and prostaglandins, which cause the symptoms.
  • Symptoms: Characteristic symptoms of an allergic reaction are:
    • Facial swelling (angioedema)
    • Itching, and
    • Hypotension.
  • Histamine causes blood vessel dilation and increased permeability, leading to facial swelling and itching. In severe cases, it can induce hypotension and trigger anaphylaxis.

 

IgA (Option A) is primarily involved in mucosal immunity, protecting the mucous membranes of the respiratory, digestive, and genitourinary tracts. It is not typically associated with immediate hypersensitivity reactions like those seen in response to bee stings.

IgM (Option C) is the first antibody produced during an immune response. It is involved in the primary immune response and is not specifically associated with allergic reactions or the symptoms described in the scenario.

IgG (Option D) is the most abundant antibody in the bloodstream and is involved in long-term immunity. While IgG can play a role in some types of allergic reactions, it is not the primary immunoglobulin responsible for the immediate hypersensitivity reactions seen in response to a bee sting.

questions.text: Which type of cells are implicated in the development of contact dermatitis in a 12-year-old boy who presented to the emergency department?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Helper T cells

Explanation:

  • Contact dermatitis is an inflammatory skin condition that occurs when the skin comes into contact with an allergen or irritant.
  • The pathogenesis involves a complex interplay between various immune cells, including antigen-presenting cells (such as dendritic cells), T cells (including helper T cells), and other immune mediators.
  • Helper T cells are activated upon recognition of the allergen, and they release cytokines that recruit and activate other immune cells, leading to the characteristic inflammation and skin reactions seen in contact dermatitis.
  • The type of hypersensitivity involved in contact dermatitis is Type IV.

Mechanisms of Type IV hypersensitivity

Description

Examples

Cytokine-mediated inflammation
(mediated by CD4+ T cells)
  • CD4+ T cells recognise protein antigens presented by APCs and differentiate into Th1 and Th17 cells.
  • Th1 cells secrete cytokines like IFN-γ, activating macrophages to cause tissue damage and fibrosis.
  • Th17 cells produce IL-17 to recruit neutrophils, promoting inflammation.
  • Tuberculin test (a classic example of delayed-type hypersensitivity)
  • Granulomas
  • Contact dermatitis
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • IBD
  • Psoriasis

T cell-mediated cytotoxicity (mediated by CD8+ T cells)

 

 
  • Cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs) directly kill antigen-bearing target cells, including tumour cells, virus-infected cells, and allogeneic tissue, during graft rejection.
  • CTLs use perforin-granzyme-dependent killing and Fas-Fas ligand-dependent killing mechanisms to induce apoptosis in target cells.
  • Type 1 DM
  • Hepatic injury in HBV infection
  • Graft vs host disease

  • Helper T cells play a crucial role in the immune response by coordinating and regulating other immune cells.
  • They release cytokines that activate and recruit other cells to the site of inflammation, including in the case of contact dermatitis.

 

Neutrophils (Option B) are typically involved in acute inflammation and play a major role in fighting bacterial infections. While neutrophils may be recruited to the site of inflammation in some cases of contact dermatitis, they are not the primary cells involved in the pathogenesis of the condition.

NK cells (Option C) are a type of cytotoxic lymphocyte that plays a role in the innate immune response. They are primarily involved in recognising and eliminating virally infected and tumour cells. NK cells are not typically the primary cells involved in contact dermatitis.

Cytotoxic T cells (Option B) are a type of T lymphocyte that directly kills infected or abnormal cells. They play a critical role in the immune response against viruses and tumour cells. While they may be involved in certain immune responses, they are not the primary cells in contact dermatitis.

questions.text: A patient underwent a bone marrow transplant without HLA matching. In which of the following disorders transplant rejection does not occur:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Bare lymphocyte syndrome

Explanation:

  • Bone marrow transplant (BMT) rejection is mediated by recipient T lymphocytes recognizing donor HLA antigens as foreign. Therefore, the integrity and function of recipient T cells (especially CD8⁺ cytotoxic T cells) are crucial for mounting a rejection response.

Bare Lymphocyte Syndrome (BLS):

  • It is a type of MHC class II deficiency, and in some forms, MHC class I expression is also defective.
  • Because of absent or defective HLA expression, CD4⁺ (helper) and sometimes CD8⁺ (cytotoxic) T cells are profoundly dysfunctional or absent.
  • Result: These patients are immunologically unable to recognize or reject transplanted tissue, even in the absence of HLA matching.

Hence, rejection does not occur in BLS due to lack of HLA molecule expression and impaired T cell function.

Chediak-Higashi Syndrome (Option B) is an autosomal recessive condition with defect in lysosomal trafficking regulator gene (LYST), leading to defective neutrophil function.

T and B cell immunity is relatively intact — rejection is possible.

Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome (Option C) X-linked disorder with combined immunodeficiency, characterized by thrombocytopenia, eczema, and recurrent infection. It is caused by mutations in the gene located at Xp11.23 that encodes Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASP). Although T-cell dysfunction is present, it is not severe enough to completely prevent rejection.

Job’s Syndrome (Hyper-IgE syndrome) (Option C) Impaired Th17 pathway with eosinophilia and recurrent infections. T cell immunity is abnormal but not absent, so rejection can occur.

questions.text: Blood transfusion reactions are mediated by which type of hypersensitivity reaction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Type II

Explanation:

  • Blood transfusion reactions (specifically acute hemolytic transfusion reactions) occur when the recipient’s immune system attacks donor red blood cells due to ABO incompatibility.

Mechanism:

  • Type of hypersensitivity: Type II (antibody-mediated cytotoxic).
  • Pathophysiology:
    1. Pre-existing IgM antibodies in the recipient bind to antigens (A or B) on donor RBCs.
    2. This activates the complement cascade, leading to:
      • RBC lysis (intravascular hemolysis)
      • Release of haemoglobin
      • Inflammatory cytokine release
    3. Clinical presentation: fever, chills, hypotension, flank pain, hemoglobinuria, possible DIC.

Type I (Option A): IgE-mediated (allergies, anaphylaxis).

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with a history of recurrent bacterial and fungal infections, particularly involving the skin and respiratory tract. The patient's parents report that he has had multiple abscesses and lymphadenitis. Dihydrorhodamine test results show an abnormal pattern. What is the primary suspicion based on these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) CGD

Explanation:

The history of recurrent bacterial and fungal infections, especially affecting the skin and respiratory tract, along with multiple abscesses, lymphadenitis, and an abnormal Dihydrorhodamine (DHR) test result, strongly suggests Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD).

  • It is characterised by increased susceptibility to recurrent infections caused by catalase-positive organisms.
  • Cause: Defect in NADPH oxidase, an enzyme complex in phagocytes.
  • Mechanism: A defect in NADPH oxidase leads to the inability to produce the reactive oxygen species (ROS) required to kill certain bacteria and fungi.
  • Clinical Presentation: Recurrent infections, particularly with catalase-positive organisms (e.g., Staphylococcus aureus, Aspergillus), granuloma formation.
  • This defect is identified by the abnormal DHR test, which measures the production of ROS in neutrophils.

 

SCID (Severe Combined Immunodeficiency) (Option B) is a genetic disorder affecting both humoral and cell-mediated immunity, presenting with thrush, diaper rash, and failure to thrive in infants. It involves defects in T and B cells, leading to severe, broad immune deficiencies, unlike the phagocyte-specific defect seen in CGD.

Sialyl Lewis X (Option C) is a carbohydrate on leukocytes that helps with adhesion and migration during immune responses. Its deficiency impairs neutrophil trafficking, leading to immune deficiency and recurrent infections, but does not typically cause abnormalities in the DHR test.

LAD (Leukocyte Adhesion Deficiency) (Option D) is a genetic disorder causing defective neutrophil adhesion, impairing migration to infection sites, leading to recurrent infections, poor wound healing, and delayed umbilical cord separation. The DHR test is normal in LAD, as it assesses phagocyte function, not adhesion.

questions.text: Which of the following genes is responsible for the regulation of T lymphocytes by the thymus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) AIRE

Explanation:

  • AIRE (autoimmune regulator) is a gene responsible for regulating T cell selection in the thymus.
  • During negative selection, T cells that recognize self-antigens are eliminated through apoptosis.
  • AIRE plays a crucial role in this process by promoting the deletion of self-reactive T cells.
  • A defect in AIRE results in autoimmune polyendocrine syndrome (APS).

Notch 1 (Option B) is involved in the initial development of T cells, including determining whether a progenitor cell will become a T cell, but it does not regulate the elimination of self-reactive T cells, which is the role of AIRE.

E2A (Option C) is a transcription factor more relevant to B cell development and not directly related to T cell selection in the thymus.

Rag1/2 (Option D) are enzymes responsible for the rearrangement of T cell receptor (TCR) genes during T cell development, but they do not directly regulate negative selection.

questions.text: What does CD40 deficiency in a person signify?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) B cell absent

Explanation:

  • In individuals with CD40 deficiency, B cell activation is impaired.
  • CD40 is a crucial co-stimulatory molecule involved in the activation and regulation of the immune response, particularly between T cells and B cells
  • CD40L (also known as CD154) on antigen-activated CD4+ helper T cells binds to CD40 on B cells, macrophages, and dendritic cells (DCs).
  • In the absence of CD40, B cells cannot receive the necessary co-stimulatory signals required for proper activation and class switching.
  • It results in a lack of IgG production (Option D ruled out) despite the presence of IgM. It leads to a condition known as Hyper-IgM syndrome.

T cell absent (Option B): CD40 deficiency does not lead to an absence of T cells. T cells are present, but the CD40 deficiency impairs the interaction between T cells and B cells.

IgM increase (Option C): Although IgM levels may be elevated in some cases due to lack of class switching, the key feature is failure to produce IgG and other antibody isotypes, leading to impaired immunity.

questions.text: After class switching, a particular class of antibody is produced, but IgM and IgD are expressed concomitantly on the surface of a B cell due to which of the following phenomena?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Alternate RNA splicing

Explanation:

  • B cells express both IgM and IgD antibodies simultaneously due to alternative RNA splicing.
  • This mechanism allows the same heavy chain gene to be spliced in different ways, resulting in the production of both IgM and IgD isotypes.
  • Although IgM and IgD are derived from the same heavy chain gene, the splicing process generates distinct versions of the RNA transcript, one for IgM and one for IgD.
  • Both antibodies share the same antigen-binding specificity but differ in their constant regions, which determine their respective isotypes.

Allelic exclusion (Option A) ensures that only one allele of the immunoglobulin gene is expressed in a B cell at a time, maintaining clonal specificity, but it does not account for the co-expression of IgM and IgD.

Somatic hypermutation (Option C) takes place after antigen exposure and enhances the affinity of antibodies, but it does not play a role in the simultaneous expression of IgM and IgD.

Affinity maturation (Option D) is a process that improves antibody affinity during the immune response, but it does not generate multiple antibody classes concurrently.

questions.text: Which of the following is implicated in the pathogenesis of rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Autoimmunity

Explanation:

  • Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic autoimmune disorder where the immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissues.
  • The pathogenesis of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) begins with antigenic exposure in genetically predisposed individuals, leading to the activation of CD4+ T-cells.
  • These T-cells release inflammatory cytokines such as TNF-α, IL-1, IL-6, and interferon-γ, which activate endothelial cells, B lymphocytes, and macrophages.
  • This cascade of immune activation leads to chronic inflammation, joint damage, and deformities that characterise RA.

Epidemiology

  • Peaks between 25 and 55 years.
  • Remains constant between 55 and 75.

Genetics

  • Higher concordance in monozygotic twins.

Triggers and suppressors

  • Cigarette smoking and infections can trigger RA in genetically predisposed individuals by citrullination of proteins.
  • RA may remit during pregnancy and can first appear postpartum due to immune suppression and hormonal changes.

Pathogenesis

Chronic microbial infections (Option D) can trigger or exacerbate autoimmune diseases, but they are not the direct cause of RA. However, certain infections may contribute to disease flares or trigger the initial immune response.

questions.text: A Rh-negative mother delivered an Rh-positive baby, and Coomb’s test was positive for the baby. What is the mechanism of hypersensitivity seen in this scenario?

questions.text: In a patient with Bare Lymphocyte Syndrome, graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) does not occur. Which of the following causes it?

choices.text: MHC Class II deficiency in lymphocytes
MHC Class I deficiency in lymphocytes

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) MHC Class II deficiency in lymphocytes

Explanation: 

Bare Lymphocyte Syndrome (BLS) caused by MHC Class II deficiency (most common form) prevents the development of CD4+ T cells, which are essential for initiating graft-versus-host disease (GVHD).

 

Bare Lymphocyte Syndrome:

  • Typically caused by mutations in transcription factors essential for the expression of Class II MHC genes.
    • The absence of Class II MHC molecules leads to the underdevelopment of CD4+ T cells, which play a crucial role in cellular immunity and assist B cells. As a result, Class II MHC deficiency results in a combined immunodeficiency.
  • Additionally, other forms of the syndrome can be caused by mutations in antigen receptor chains or signalling molecules critical for the maturation of T or B cells.

 

Complement deficiency (Option A) does not affect T cell function or MHC expression, making it unrelated to GVHD, which requires donor T cell recognition of host MHC.

 

MHC Class II deficiency in lymphocytes (Option C) describes the cause of Bare Lymphocyte Syndrome but does not directly cause GVHD; instead, it prevents CD4⁺ T cell development, making GVHD unlikely.

 

MHC Class I deficiency in lymphocytes (Option D) affects CD8⁺ T cell function but does not significantly impair CD4⁺ T cell-mediated GVHD, which relies on MHC Class II recognition.

questions.text: A boy presents with recurrent episodes of melena. On examination, there is eczema of the skin with multiple petechiae. His platelet count is low, with normal RBC and WBC counts. Which of the following is the diagnostic investigation for this patient?
questions.solution:
• The patient's presentation of recurrent melena (indicative of gastrointestinal bleeding), eczema, petechiae (small skin haemorrhages), and low platelet count with normal RBC and WBC counts suggests Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome (WAS), an X-linked recessive disease characterized by the triad of:
    • Thrombocytopenia
    • Eczema
    • Recurrent infections
  • It is caused by mutations in the gene located at Xp11.23, which encodes the Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASP).
  • WASP belongs to a family of proteins that are believed to link membrane receptors, such as antigen receptors, to cytoskeletal elements.
  • IgM levels in the serum are low, but levels of IgG are usually normal.
  • Paradoxically, the levels of IgA and IgE are often elevated. Patients are also prone to developing B-cell lymphomas.
  • WASP may be involved in cytoskeleton-dependent responses, including cell migration and signal transduction.
  • It may lead to early death. The only treatment is hematopoietic stem cell (HSC) transplantation.

 

Anti-platelet antibodies (Option B) are typically found in conditions like immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP), but the patient's history and presentation point more toward WAS.

 

Bone marrow biopsy (Option C) is generally used to assess hematologic disorders like leukaemia or myelodysplastic syndromes, which do not match this case.

 

Electron microscopy (Option D) is helpful for diagnosing certain intracellular abnormalities, but it's not the first diagnostic test for WAS.

questions.text: A young person with recurrent seasonal conjunctivitis presents with itchiness and eye-watering. What is the most likely cell involved in the immediate phase of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Mast cells

Explanation:

  • The condition described is allergic conjunctivitis, where the immediate phase involves an IgE-mediated hypersensitivity reaction, with mast cells playing a central role in the response.
  • Type I Hypersensitivity (early) is an immediate IgE-mediated reaction where mast cells release histamine and other mediators upon allergen exposure, causing itching, eye-watering, redness, and swelling.
  • There are two phases in Type I hypersensitivity: the immediate and late-phase responses.

questions.text: True about anaphylactoid reactions are all except:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - IgE-mediated:

  • Anaphylactoid reactions are not mediated by IgE antibodies.
  • Unlike true anaphylaxis, anaphylactoid reactions are triggered by non-immunologic mechanisms, such as the direct activation of mast cells or the complement system.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Involves degranulation of mast cells:

  • Anaphylactoid reactions involve the rapid release of mediators, such as histamine, from mast cells and basophils.
  • These mediators cause symptoms similar to those seen in anaphylaxis, but anaphylactoid reactions are not IgE-mediated.

Option C - Can occur on first exposure:

  • Anaphylactoid reactions can occur on the first exposure to a triggering agent.
  • Unlike some allergic reactions that require sensitization and previous exposure, anaphylactoid reactions can happen without prior exposure or sensitization.

Option D - Can be caused by NSAIDs:

  • NSAIDs (non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs) can potentially trigger anaphylactoid reactions, but they are not the most common cause.
  • Anaphylactoid reactions can be caused by various substances, such as certain drugs (e.g., contrast media), radiocontrast dyes, intravenous fluids, and some food additives.
  • It is important to note that anaphylactoid reactions to NSAIDs are not IgE-mediated but rather due to direct activation of mast cells.

questions.text: Which of the following cells is responsible for graft rejection?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - T cells:

  • When a graft is transplanted into a recipient, the immune system recognizes the graft as foreign and triggers an immune response.
  • This response is primarily mediated by T cells, which can recognize and respond to specific foreign antigens.
  • The T cells recognize and bind to the foreign antigens expressed by the graft.
  • This triggers the activation of other immune cells, such as macrophages, which can help to engulf and destroy the foreign tissue.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Seminiferous tubule:

  • The seminiferous tubules in the testes are considered immune privilege sites.
  • These tubules play a crucial role in sperm production.
  • The blood-testis barrier, formed by specialized cells in the walls of the seminiferous tubules, limits the immune response within the testes.

questions.text: The X-ray of a middle-aged man showed multiple lytic lesions, following which a urine examination was done. The sample revealed Bence Jones proteins. Which is the most common immunoglobulin associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - IgG:

  • The patient's presentation with multiple lytic lesions on X-ray and Bence-Jones proteins in urine examination is suggestive of multiple myeloma.
  • In multiple myeloma, abnormal plasma cells accumulate in the bone marrow and produce excessive amounts of a single type of antibody, or immunoglobulin.
  • Bence Jones proteins are fragments of immunoglobulin light chains that are filtered by the kidneys and excreted in the urine.
  • The most common immunoglobulin associated with multiple myeloma is IgG, which accounts for about 50% of cases.
  • IgA is the second most common type, accounting for about 20-25% of cases.
  • IgM is rare in multiple myeloma, and IgD is not typically associated with this condition.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: Gamma delta T cell (yδ) receptors recognize:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Lipids without MHC proteins:

  • Gamma delta T cell (γδ) receptors are capable of recognizing lipids without the need for major histocompatibility complex (MHC) proteins.
  • This means that γδ T cells can directly interact with certain lipids, glycolipids, and phospholipids, allowing them to respond to lipid antigens independently of MHC presentation.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Peptides with MHC proteins:

  • Alpha beta T cell receptors (αβ TCRs) are predominantly responsible for recognizing peptide antigens, which are typically presented by MHC molecules on the surface of antigen-presenting cells (APCs).
  • Peptides derived from pathogens or abnormal cellular processes are presented by MHC molecules, and αβ TCRs bind to these peptide-MHC complexes to initiate an immune response.

Option C - CD20:

  • CD20 is a cell surface protein expressed primarily on the surface of B cells.
  • It is not directly related to the recognition of antigens by T-cell receptors.
  • CD20 is mainly targeted by therapeutic antibodies in the treatment of certain B-cell lymphomas and autoimmune diseases, such as rheumatoid arthritis and multiple sclerosis.

Option D - CD3:

  • CD3 is a complex of proteins associated with the T cell receptor (TCR) on the surface of T cells.
  • It is involved in the signal transduction process upon TCR engagement with peptide-MHC complexes.
  • CD3 proteins transmit activation signals to the T cell when the TCR recognizes its specific antigen, leading to T cell activation and an immune response.
  • CD3 is not directly responsible for antigen recognition but is crucial for T-cell signalling.

questions.text: Toluidine blue staining is used in the identification of which of the following cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Mast cell:

  • Toluidine blue staining is primarily used for the identification of mast cells.
  • Mast cells contain metachromatic granules that can be selectively stained by toluidine blue.
  • The dye binds to the granules, causing them to appear purple or blue.
  • This staining technique helps visualize and identify mast cells in histological sections, particularly in the assessment of mast cell-related diseases such as mastocytosis or allergic reactions.

Incorrect Options:

  • Toluidine blue staining is not used for options A, B, and C.

questions.text: Antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC) is seen with :
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - NK cells, Neutrophils, and Eosinophils:

  • NK cells, neutrophils, and eosinophils are all involved in ADCC.
  • NK cells have Fc receptors that enable them to recognize and destroy antibody-bound target cells.
  • Neutrophils and eosinophils also possess Fc receptors and can participate in ADCC by releasing cytotoxic substances or producing reactive oxygen species to eliminate antibody-coated cells.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding amyloidosis?

choices.text: SAA forms amyloid in multiple myeloma
On Congo red staining, amyloid shows apple green birefringence
In AL type amyloid is most commonly formed from kappa chain
β2 - macroglobulin forms amyloid in systemic senile amyloidosis

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - On Congo red staining, amyloid shows apple green birefringence:

  • Congo red, when used in conjunction with polarized light microscopy, produces a characteristic apple green birefringence in amyloid deposits.
  • This staining property is a key diagnostic feature of amyloidosis and helps differentiate amyloid deposits from other substances.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - SAA forms amyloid in multiple myeloma: In multiple myeloma, amyloidosis is usually associated with the deposition of immunoglobulin light chains, specifically the lambda chain, known as AL amyloidosis.

Option C - In AL type amyloid is most commonly formed from kappa chain: In AL amyloidosis, the amyloid fibrils are most commonly formed from the lambda chain.

Option D - β2-macroglobulin forms amyloid in systemic senile amyloidosis: Systemic senile amyloidosis is most commonly associated with the deposition of amyloid fibrils derived from transthyretin.

questions.text: Which gene is not involved in SCID?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - BTK:

  • BTK is involved in X-linked agammaglobulinemia (XLA), which is a primary immunodeficiency disorder characterized by the absence or significantly reduced levels of mature B cells.
  • Mutations in the BTK gene impair B cell development and function, leading to a lack of antibody production.
  • XLA is not considered severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID).

Incorrect Options:

Option B - JAK-3:

  • Mutations in the JAK-3 gene can cause severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID).
  • JAK-3 is involved in the signalling pathway of certain cytokines important for immune cell development and function.
  • Loss-of-function mutations in JAK-3 disrupt the development of T cells, B cells, and natural killer (NK) cells, resulting in SCID.

Option C - RAG1:

  • Mutations in the RAG1 gene can cause severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID).
  • RAG1 is crucial for the rearrangement of immunoglobulin and T cell receptor genes during lymphocyte development.
  • Loss-of-function mutations in RAG1 impair the development of functional T and B cells, leading to SCID.

Option D - IL-7Rα:

  • Mutations in the IL-7Rα gene can cause severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID).
  • IL-7Rα is a subunit of the receptor for interleukin-7, a cytokine involved in the development and survival of T cells.
  • Defects in IL-7Rα lead to impaired T cell development, resulting in SCID.

questions.text: Which of the following is a type-2 hypersensitivity reaction?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Autoimmune hemolytic anaemia:

  • Type-2 hypersensitivity reactions are mediated by antibodies, particularly IgG or IgM, binding to antigens on the surface of target cells, leading to their destruction or dysfunction.
  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia is an example of a type-2 hypersensitivity reaction.
  • In autoimmune hemolytic anemia, autoantibodies are produced against the antigens on the surface of red blood cells, resulting in their premature destruction by phagocytes in the spleen and liver.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Chronic kidney rejection:

  • Chronic kidney rejection involves a complex immune response, including cellular and humoral components.

Option C - Arthus reaction:

  • Arthus reaction is a localized immune complex-mediated hypersensitivity reaction that occurs when preformed antibodies react with antigens in the blood vessel walls, leading to inflammation and tissue damage.
  • It is considered a type-3 hypersensitivity reaction.

Option D - Mantoux test:

  • Mantoux test is a type-4 hypersensitivity reaction.

questions.text: Which of the following about γδ T-cells is incorrect?

choices.text: Kills extracellular bacteria by granulysin and perforin
Need antigen processing and presentation for its recognition

questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Need antigen processing and presentation for its recognition

Explanation:

  • αβ T-cells and γδ T-cells do not require antigen processing and presentation by major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules for recognition.
  • They can recognize and respond to antigens directly, including certain stress-induced molecules and microbial products.

Incorrect Options:

Kills extracellular bacteria by granulysin and perforin (Option A):

  • γδ T-cells can kill extracellular bacteria through the release of granulysin and perforin, which are cytotoxic molecules.

Direct killing of infected macrophages (Option C):

  • γδ T-cells can directly kill infected macrophages, which helps in the control of intracellular infections.

Provide protection against mycobacteria (Option D):

  • γδ T-cells have been shown to provide protection against mycobacterial infections, including Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the causative agent of tuberculosis.
  • They contribute to the immune response by producing cytokines and exerting cytotoxic effects.

questions.text: Xenograft is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Graft across species:

  • Xenograft refers to a type of graft or transplantation that involves transferring tissues or organs from one species to another.

questions.text: What is the single most important long-term limitation of cardiac transplantation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Allograft Arteriopathy:

  • The single most important long-term limitation of cardiac transplantation is allograft arteriopathy, also known as cardiac allograft vasculopathy (CAV).
  • Allograft arteriopathy refers to the progressive narrowing and occlusion of the coronary arteries of the transplanted heart.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents to the clinic complaining of severe abdominal pain and headaches for the past two days. He has a history of myalgia and several episodes of vomiting. His parents self-medicated with paracetamol, but the patient had no relief. A dengue NS-1 antigen test was ordered, which came out positive. What is the first line of defence for the body in the given scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Natural Killer cells:

  • In the given case of a positive dengue NS-1 antigen test, the first line of defense of the body would involve the activation of NK cells.
  • NK cells are a type of lymphocyte that plays a crucial role in the innate immune response against viral infections.
  • They can recognize and eliminate virus-infected cells without prior exposure or specific recognition of the virus.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are not the primary first-line defense against viral infections in the given case.

questions.text: Type II Hypersensitivity is seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pernicious Anaemia:

  • In pernicious anemia, the immune system produces antibodies against intrinsic factors or parietal cells in the stomach.
  • These antibodies interfere with the absorption of vitamin B12, leading to its deficiency.
  • It is an example of type II hypersensitivity.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Serum sickness:

  • Serum sickness is a type III hypersensitivity reaction that occurs in response to the administration of certain medications or the injection of foreign proteins, such as antivenoms or serum.
  • It involves the formation of immune complexes that deposit in various tissues and activate the complement system.

Option C - Arthus phenomenon:

  • Arthus phenomenon is a localized immune complex-mediated hypersensitivity reaction.
  • It occurs when there is an excessive immune response at the site of antigen exposure, usually due to repeated exposure to an antigen.

Option D - Pathergy phenomenon:

  • Pathergy phenomenon refers to the development of a skin lesion in response to minor trauma or injury.
  • It is commonly seen in certain conditions, like Behçet's disease.

questions.text: Basophils are activated by?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - IL-5:

  • Basophils, along with eosinophils and mast cells, are activated by IL-5, which is an interleukin involved in the regulation of immune responses, particularly in allergic reactions and parasitic infections.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - INF-gamma: INF-gamma primarily activates macrophages and plays a role in cellular immune responses.

Option C - TNF-alpha: TNF-alpha is a cytokine produced by activated macrophages and other immune cells.

Option D - IL-2: IL-2 stimulates the proliferation and activation of T-cells and natural killer (NK) cells.
